title: Which AI model should I use with GitHub Copilot?
description: Ever wondered which AI model is the best fit for your GitHub Copilot project? Here are some things to consider. The post Which AI model should I use with GitHub Copilot? appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
author: Cassidy Williams
excerpt: Ever wondered which AI model is the best fit for your GitHub Copilot project? Here are some things to consider.
text: This was originally published on our developer newsletter, GitHub Insider, which offers tips and tricks for devs at every level. If you‚Äôre not subscribed, go do that now‚Äîyou won‚Äôt regret it (we promise). If you‚Äôve ever wondered which AI model is the best fit for your GitHub Copilot project, you‚Äôre not alone. Since each model has its own strengths, picking the right one can feel somewhat mysterious. With models that prioritize speed, depth, or a balance of both, it helps to know what each one brings to the table. Let‚Äôs break it down together. üëá The TL;DR üí≥ Balance between cost and performance: Go with GPT-4.1, GPT-4o, or Claude 3.5 Sonnet. ü™ô Fast, lightweight tasks: o4-mini or Claude 3.5 Sonnet are your buddies. üíé Deep reasoning or complex debugging: Think Claude 3.7 Sonnet, o3, or GPT 4.5. üñºÔ∏è Multimodal inputs (like images): Check out Gemini 2.0 Flash or GPT-4o. Your mileage may vary and it‚Äôs always good to try things yourself before taking someone else‚Äôs word for it, but this is how these models were designed to be used. All that being said‚Ä¶ Let‚Äôs talk models. üèéÔ∏è AI models designed for coding speed o4-mini and o3-mini: The speed demons üòà Fast, efficient, and cost-effective, o4-mini and o3-mini are ideal for simple coding questions and quick iterations. If you‚Äôre looking for a no-frills model, use these. ‚úÖ Use them for: Quick prototyping. Explaining code snippets. Learning new programming concepts. Generating boilerplate code. üëÄ You may prefer another model: If your task spans multiple files or calls for deep reasoning, a higher‚Äëcapacity model such as GPT‚Äë4.5 or o3 can keep more context in mind. Looking for extra expressive flair? Try GPT‚Äë4o. ‚öñÔ∏è AI models designed for balance Claude 3.5 Sonnet: The budget-friendly helper üòä Need solid performance but watching your costs? Claude 3.5 Sonnet is like a dependable sidekick. It‚Äôs great for everyday coding tasks without burning through your monthly usage. ‚úÖ Use it for: Writing documentation. Answering language-specific questions. Generating code snippets. üëÄ You may prefer another model: For elaborate multi‚Äëstep reasoning or big‚Äëpicture planning, consider stepping up to Claude 3.7 Sonnet or GPT‚Äë4.5. GPT-4o and GPT-4.1: The all-rounders üåé These are your go-to models for general tasks. Need fast responses? Check. Want to work with text *and* images? Double check. GPT-4o and GPT-4.1 are like the Swiss Army knives of AI models: flexible, dependable, and cost-efficient. ‚úÖ Use them for: Explaining code blocks. Writing comments or docs. Generating small, reusable snippets. Multilingual prompts. üëÄ You may prefer another model: Complex architectural reasoning or multi‚Äëstep debugging may land more naturally with GPT‚Äë4.5 or Claude 3.7 Sonnet. üß† AI models designed for deep thinking and big projects Claude 3.7 Sonnet: The architect üè† This one‚Äôs the power tool for large, complex projects. From multi-file refactoring to feature development across front end and back end, Claude 3.7 Sonnet shines when context and depth matter most. ‚úÖ Use it for: Refactoring large codebases. Planning complex architectures. Designing algorithms. Combining high-level summaries with deep analysis. üëÄ You may prefer another model: For quick iterations or straightforward tasks, Claude 3.5 Sonnet or GPT‚Äë4o may deliver results with less overhead. Gemini 2.5 Pro: The researcher üîé Gemini 2.5 Pro is the powerhouse for advanced reasoning and coding. It‚Äôs built for complex tasks (think: deep debugging, algorithm design, and even scientific research). With its long-context capabilities, it can handle extensive datasets or documents with ease. ‚úÖ Use it for: Writing full functions, classes, or multi-file logic. Debugging complex systems. Analyzing scientific data and generating insights. Processing long documents, datasets, or codebases. üëÄ You may prefer another model: For cost-sensitive tasks, o4-mini or Gemini 2.0 Flash are more budget-friendly options. GPT-4.5: The thinker üí≠ Got a tricky problem? Whether you‚Äôre debugging multi-step issues or crafting full-on systems architectures, GPT-4.5 thrives on nuance and complexity. ‚úÖ Use it for: Writing detailed README files. Generating full functions or multi-file solutions. Debugging complex errors. Making architectural decisions. üëÄ You may prefer another model: When you just need a quick iteration on something small‚Äîor you‚Äôre watching tokens‚ÄîGPT‚Äë4o can finish faster and cheaper. o3 and o1: The deep diver ü•Ω These models are perfect for tasks that need precision and logic. Whether you‚Äôre optimizing performance-critical code or refactoring a messy codebase, o3 and o1 excel in breaking down problems step by step. ‚úÖ Use them for: Code optimization. Debugging complex systems. Writing structured, reusable code. Summarizing logs or benchmarks. üëÄ You may prefer another model: During early prototyping or lightweight tasks, a nimble model such as o4‚Äëmini or GPT‚Äë4o may feel snappier. üñºÔ∏è Multimodal AI models designed to handle it all Gemini 2.0 Flash: The visual thinker ü§î Got visual inputs like UI mockups or diagrams? Gemini 2.0 Flash lets you bring images into the mix, making it a great choice for front-end prototyping or layout debugging. ‚úÖ Use it for: Analyzing diagrams or screenshots. Debugging UI layouts. Generating code snippets. Getting design feedback. üëÄ You may prefer another model: If the job demands step‚Äëby‚Äëstep algorithmic reasoning, GPT‚Äë4.5 or Claude 3.7 Sonnet will keep more moving parts in scope. So‚Ä¶ which model do I choose? Here‚Äôs the rule of thumb: Match the model to the task. Practice really does make perfect, and as you work with different models, it‚Äôll become clearer which ones work best for different tasks. The more I‚Äôve personally used certain models, the more I‚Äôve learned, ‚Äúoh, I should switch for this particular task,‚Äù and ‚Äúthis one will get me there.‚Äù And because I enjoy staying employed, I would love to cheekily mention that you can (and should!) use these models with‚Ä¶ GitHub Copilot in your favorite IDE GitHub Copilot on GitHub.com With agent mode or Copilot Edits With agent mode in Codespaces With agent mode in VS Code Good luck, go forth, and happy coding! Written by Sr. Director, Developer Advocacy, GitHub Related posts Explore more from GitHub Docs Everything you need to master GitHub, all in one place. html:
This was originally published on our developer newsletter, GitHub Insider, which offers tips and tricks for devs at every level. If you‚Äôre not subscribed, go do that now‚Äîyou won‚Äôt regret it (we promise).

If you‚Äôve ever wondered which AI model is the best fit for your GitHub Copilot project, you‚Äôre not alone. Since each model has its own strengths, picking the right one can feel somewhat mysterious.

With models that prioritize speed, depth, or a balance of both, it helps to know what each one brings to the table. Let‚Äôs break it down together. üëá

The TL;DR

  • üí≥ Balance between cost and performance: Go with GPT-4.1, GPT-4o, or Claude 3.5 Sonnet.
  • ü™ô Fast, lightweight tasks: o4-mini or Claude 3.5 Sonnet are your buddies.
  • üíé Deep reasoning or complex debugging: Think Claude 3.7 Sonnet, o3, or GPT 4.5.
  • üñºÔ∏è Multimodal inputs (like images): Check out Gemini 2.0 Flash or GPT-4o.

Your mileage may vary and it‚Äôs always good to try things yourself before taking someone else‚Äôs word for it, but this is how these models were designed to be used. All that being said‚Ä¶

Let‚Äôs talk models.

üèéÔ∏è AI models designed for coding speed

o4-mini and o3-mini: The speed demons üòà

Fast, efficient, and cost-effective, o4-mini and o3-mini are ideal for simple coding questions and quick iterations. If you‚Äôre looking for a no-frills model, use these.

‚úÖ Use them for:

  • Quick prototyping.
  • Explaining code snippets.
  • Learning new programming concepts.
  • Generating boilerplate code.

üëÄ You may prefer another model: If your task spans multiple files or calls for deep reasoning, a higher‚Äëcapacity model such as GPT‚Äë4.5 or o3 can keep more context in mind. Looking for extra expressive flair? Try GPT‚Äë4o.

‚öñÔ∏è AI models designed for balance

Claude 3.5 Sonnet: The budget-friendly helper üòä

Need solid performance but watching your costs? Claude 3.5 Sonnet is like a dependable sidekick. It‚Äôs great for everyday coding tasks without burning through your monthly usage.

‚úÖ Use it for:

  • Writing documentation.
  • Answering language-specific questions.
  • Generating code snippets.

üëÄ You may prefer another model: For elaborate multi‚Äëstep reasoning or big‚Äëpicture planning, consider stepping up to Claude 3.7 Sonnet or GPT‚Äë4.5.

GPT-4o and GPT-4.1: The all-rounders üåé

These are your go-to models for general tasks. Need fast responses? Check. Want to work with text *and* images? Double check. GPT-4o and GPT-4.1 are like the Swiss Army knives of AI models: flexible, dependable, and cost-efficient.

‚úÖ Use them for:

  • Explaining code blocks.
  • Writing comments or docs.
  • Generating small, reusable snippets.
  • Multilingual prompts.

üëÄ You may prefer another model: Complex architectural reasoning or multi‚Äëstep debugging may land more naturally with GPT‚Äë4.5 or Claude 3.7 Sonnet.

üß† AI models designed for deep thinking and big projects

Claude 3.7 Sonnet: The architect üè†

This one‚Äôs the power tool for large, complex projects. From multi-file refactoring to feature development across front end and back end, Claude 3.7 Sonnet shines when context and depth matter most.

‚úÖ Use it for:

  • Refactoring large codebases.
  • Planning complex architectures.
  • Designing algorithms.
  • Combining high-level summaries with deep analysis.

üëÄ You may prefer another model: For quick iterations or straightforward tasks, Claude 3.5 Sonnet or GPT‚Äë4o may deliver results with less overhead.

Gemini 2.5 Pro: The researcher üîé

Gemini 2.5 Pro is the powerhouse for advanced reasoning and coding. It‚Äôs built for complex tasks (think: deep debugging, algorithm design, and even scientific research). With its long-context capabilities, it can handle extensive datasets or documents with ease.

‚úÖ Use it for:

  • Writing full functions, classes, or multi-file logic.
  • Debugging complex systems.
  • Analyzing scientific data and generating insights.
  • Processing long documents, datasets, or codebases.

üëÄ You may prefer another model: For cost-sensitive tasks, o4-mini or Gemini 2.0 Flash are more budget-friendly options.

GPT-4.5: The thinker üí≠

Got a tricky problem? Whether you‚Äôre debugging multi-step issues or crafting full-on systems architectures, GPT-4.5 thrives on nuance and complexity.

‚úÖ Use it for:

  • Writing detailed README files.
  • Generating full functions or multi-file solutions.
  • Debugging complex errors.
  • Making architectural decisions.

üëÄ You may prefer another model: When you just need a quick iteration on something small‚Äîor you‚Äôre watching tokens‚ÄîGPT‚Äë4o can finish faster and cheaper.

o3 and o1: The deep diver ü•Ω

These models are perfect for tasks that need precision and logic. Whether you‚Äôre optimizing performance-critical code or refactoring a messy codebase, o3 and o1 excel in breaking down problems step by step.

‚úÖ Use them for:

  • Code optimization.
  • Debugging complex systems.
  • Writing structured, reusable code.
  • Summarizing logs or benchmarks.

üëÄ You may prefer another model: During early prototyping or lightweight tasks, a nimble model such as o4‚Äëmini or GPT‚Äë4o may feel snappier.

üñºÔ∏è Multimodal AI models designed to handle it all

Gemini 2.0 Flash: The visual thinker ü§î

Got visual inputs like UI mockups or diagrams? Gemini 2.0 Flash lets you bring images into the mix, making it a great choice for front-end prototyping or layout debugging.

‚úÖ Use it for:

  • Analyzing diagrams or screenshots.
  • Debugging UI layouts.
  • Generating code snippets.
  • Getting design feedback.

üëÄ You may prefer another model: If the job demands step‚Äëby‚Äëstep algorithmic reasoning, GPT‚Äë4.5 or Claude 3.7 Sonnet will keep more moving parts in scope.

So‚Ä¶ which model do I choose?

Here‚Äôs the rule of thumb: Match the model to the task. Practice really does make perfect, and as you work with different models, it‚Äôll become clearer which ones work best for different tasks. The more I‚Äôve personally used certain models, the more I‚Äôve learned, ‚Äúoh, I should switch for this particular task,‚Äù and ‚Äúthis one will get me there.‚Äù

And because I enjoy staying employed, I would love to cheekily mention that you can (and should!) use these models with‚Ä¶

  • GitHub Copilot in your favorite IDE
  • GitHub Copilot on GitHub.com
  • With agent mode or Copilot Edits
    • With agent mode in Codespaces
    • With agent mode in VS Code

Good luck, go forth, and happy coding!

Written by

Sr. Director, Developer Advocacy, GitHub
